awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  High Data Rate Biometric Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to advance new pressure sensors for wearables.  In car seats these sensors can help determine occupancy or measure driver attentiveness. These sensors can also be used to enable a sense of touch in robotic platforms, thereby improving automated decision-making processes. In the virtual and augmented reality sector, this system can measure force and pressure information to improve the training and learning outcomes across a range of industries, including sport, medical and military training applications. In the healthcare and wellness market, the proposed sensors would provide biometric data on high speed motions and ground reaction forces, as well as respiration and muscle fatigue information for improved outcomes.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focuses on advancing stretchable photonic sensors in the wearables industry. These elastomeric sensors are lightguides that change power output upon stretching, with the change in power output proportional to the amount of strain applied. The power output from the sensors can be calibrated towards biometric metric outputs such as high speed kinematics (joint angle velocities) and muscle fatigue (volume changes due to inflammation). Due to the soft, stretchable and thin nature of these lightguides, they can easily be integrated into garments without affecting their mechanical properties, and thereby be essentially unnoticeable to the wearer. Currently, these sensors can gather data at rates two orders of magnitude faster than the closest competitive technology. This project will focus on further increasing the data acquisition speeds and hardware testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The intent of the phase 2 NSF SBIR was to integrate our Light Lace® sensors into baseball garments and collect motion capture data x100 faster than the competition. At the same time, we needed to further improve our manufacturing capabilities in order to deliver reliable and accurate measurement tools fast. To do these, we focused on 3 major tasks: scaling Light Lace® manufacturing, field testing and signal processing. At the end of the award period, we were able to scale up manufacturing by building new equipment and exploring different methods of fiber integration. This new method and equipment allows us to control the process more efficiently, have a higher yield and require less training time. Further, we have built a custom rig to perform quality assurance tests and better understand the performance of our wearables over time. To acquire data from the sensors, we built custom printed circuit boards that allow us to power 6 Light Lace® sensors, and send the data real time to a phone via Bluetooth Low Energy. This included performing additional tests to ensure we have a high signal to noise ratio and can produce reliable boards. As we built prototypes, we worked with a baseball team to test our devices in their facilities against gold standard motion capture systems. This gave us the opportunity to get feedback from the users and improve both our hardware and software. For example, we built an additional, lower arm focused wearable upon receiving direct interest from the customer.  

Thanks to both the technical progress we made during this award period, and the relationship we built with baseball teams and MLB, we were able to raise $975K, of which $950K was raised through angel investors, and remaining from a strategic partner. We also participated in the NSF iPERF program, through which NSF funded a postdoc to work with us. Although the first impact of this technology will be in sports and more specifically baseball, the low cost, high signal to noise ratio fiberoptic sensors will open up new measurement possibilities, both in motion capture and beyond. We have been receiving a rapidly growing interest from the DoD to integrate our sensors directly into combat shirts and measure human performance metrics. Further, during the award period we relocated our company to the Boston, MA area, and were able to grow our team to 12 full time employees. This allowed us to iterate faster, and explore different form factors and opportunities within sports, DoD and more. As we grow our company and release and test more products, we plan on exploring other markets such as health (vitals, physical therapy), workforce safety, automotive (fatigue, child and pet presence), and AR/VR (gaming, training). We are also actively exploring integrating AI tools to our products to further improve our algorithms and offer individualized recommendations to our users. 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2024
Modified by: Ilayda Samilgil
